But it is very much of a piece with those films, another gorgeous and immensely satisfying reminder that there are few better directors than TÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â©chinÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â© when it comes to capturing the vagaries of the heart.

As with the director's other films, this one's ideas of romance are set against a larger political backdrop, though not in any grand or epic way. Tracing a handful of interconnected lives, ``Changing Times" explores larger global concerns as intimately as possible.

Looking trimmer than he has in years, Depardieu is Antoine, a successful land developer who's overseeing a project in that famously international city Tangier, which, of course, is where CÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â©cile (Deneuve) has been living for some years. Their son, Sami (Malik Zidi), has just blown in from Paris with a lady friend named Nadia (Lubna Azabal) and Nadia's little boy, and CÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â©cile is slightly mystified but opens her home to them anyway.
